content.content:
## Talk track (fast)

- Compressed air is **expensive electricity** in disguise
- Start with **leaks + pressure** (waste elimination)
- Next: **sequencing** and reducing unloaded run time
- Add heat recovery where thereâ€™s a good sink (space heat, process water)

**One-liner:** "We stop paying to compress air you never useâ€”then optimize controls to keep savings permanent."

## What to verify (fast)

- Compressor types and controls (load/unload, VFD)
- Pressure setpoints and where pressure drops occur
- Dryer type and dew point requirements
- Unloaded run time and staging logic
- End uses: which tools/processes truly need high pressure

**Rule:** quantify baseload and leakage first; then redesign control/sequencing around true demand.

## What to capture on-site

- Compressor nameplates, control panels, and setpoints
- Pressure at compressor discharge and at farthest critical loads
- Dryer type (refrigerated, desiccant) and condition
- Evidence of leaks (audible), condensate drains, and filter Î”P
- Run hours/cycling behavior if visible on controller

sections.title: Introduction & Fundamentals
sections.subtitle: Compressed air is one of the most expensive utilities

content.content:
# Why Compressed Air Matters

Compressed air is often called the **fourth utility** and is typically one of the **least efficient** ways to deliver energy.

Savings levers fall into two buckets:

1) **Reduce demand** (leaks, pressure, eliminate inappropriate uses)
2) **Reduce supply energy** (sequencing, VFDs, better compressor selection, heat recovery)

Operationally, compressed air is also a reliability systemâ€”bad moisture control and pressure instability cause downtime.

content.quote: The best compressor is the one that doesnâ€™t run. Fix leaks and pressure firstâ€”then youâ€™ll know what you actually need.
content.author: Industrial Energy Engineer

content.content:
## Common compressor types

- **Reciprocating**: good for intermittent loads, smaller systems
- **Rotary screw**: common for continuous industrial loads
- **Centrifugal**: large systems, steady loads

Key concept: part-load behavior matters. Poor part-load efficiency or frequent unloading is a major waste signal.

content.content:
## Why VFD can help

If demand varies, a VFD compressor can reduce unloaded operation by modulating output.

Watch-outs:
- Still need good sequencing (often one trim VFD + base units)
- VFD doesnâ€™t fix leaks or poor pressure practices

**Sales translation:** VFD is powerful after you address leaks and pressure; otherwise you may just run an oversized system more smoothly.

sections.title: Leak Detection & Repair
sections.subtitle: The highest ROI measure in many plants

content.content:
## Why leaks are so costly

Leaks run 24/7 and drive baseload compressor power.

Common leak sites:
- Quick connects and hoses
- Regulators and FRLs
- Open blow-offs
- Fittings and valves

Best practice:
- Use ultrasonic leak detection
- Tag leaks, estimate cost, and repair
- Create an ongoing leak program (savings persist)

sections.title: Pressure Optimization
sections.subtitle: Reduce setpoints safely and eliminate artificial demand

content.content:
## Why pressure costs energy

Higher pressure increases compressor power and can increase leak flow.

Steps:
1) Identify true critical pressure requirements (tools/process)
2) Fix pressure drops (filters, undersized piping, bad regulators)
3) Lower the header setpoint gradually and verify performance

**Rule-of-thumb:** every ~2 psi reduction often yields ~1% energy savings (site-specific).

sections.title: Heat Recovery
sections.subtitle: Capture compressor heat for useful loads

content.content:
## Heat recovery concept

Most compressor input power becomes heat.

Common recovery sinks:
- Space heating (warehouse/plant)
- Process water preheat
- Domestic hot water preheat

**Rule:** heat recovery works best with steady compressor operation and a steady heat demand.

## Treatment basics

- **Filters** protect equipment but add pressure drop (energy cost)
- **Dryers** remove moisture; choose dew point appropriate for the process
- **Condensate drains** must work; failed open drains waste air

**Field tip:** listen for leaking drains; they can be continuous â€œhidden leaks.â€

sections.title: Controls & Sequencing
sections.subtitle: Reduce unloaded run time and stabilize pressure

content.content:
## Sequencing goal

- Run the most efficient units at optimal load
- Use one trim unit (often VFD) to handle variability
- Avoid multiple compressors unloading simultaneously

Common issues:
- Setpoints too close causing fighting
- No central controller
- Oversized capacity relative to demand

**Sales translation:** sequencing is a controls project with strong ROI when unload time is high.

# Selling Compressed Air Projects

## Sales framing

- Compressed air is **expensive** and often unmanaged
- Start with waste elimination (leaks/pressure)
- Then tune controls for persistence

### Discovery questions
- What processes use air? Any â€œalways-onâ€ loads?
- What is header pressure set to and why?
- Do compressors run nights/weekends?
- Any moisture or quality issues causing downtime?
- Do you have metering or trending?

### Objection handling
| Objection | Response |
|---|---|
| "We need high pressure" | "We can provide high pressure locally while lowering header pressure globally." |
| "Leaks are maintenance" | "Theyâ€™re also a continuous energy costâ€”fixing them pays back quickly and improves reliability." |
| "Controls are risky" | "We implement with trending and safeguards, and we can pilot sequencing on one system first." |

questions.question: What does high unloaded run time usually indicate?
questions.explanation: High unload time means compressors are running without producing useful air, often due to poor control strategy.

questions.question: Why is heat recovery from compressors often feasible?
questions.explanation: Most electrical input to compressors ends up as heat that can sometimes be captured for useful loads.
